Identifying Characteristics: Mostly tan, brown, olive green, and gray in color
Dark lines form a telltale “X” on their back
Females are lighter-colored while males are slightly smaller and usually have dark throats
Size: Adults can reach up to 1.5 inches in length
Biology: In northern areas, they breed between March and June—when the warm rains start
Typically 900 eggs are laid per clutch but up to 1000 are possible
Egg clusters are hidden under vegetation or debris at the water base
After hatching, they transform into frogs and are ready to leave the water in about eight weeks
Hibernate under logs and loose bark in very cold weather
Call day and night as long as the temperature is above freezing, but they are mostly heard and usually not seen because they hide in dense plants
Especially easy to hear due to extremely loud mating call but it is often hard to pinpoint the source of the sound
Generally breed close to dusk and throughout the evening and early morning hours
Lifespan is estimated at three years
Habitat: Wooded areas and grassy lowlands near ponds and swamps
Loose debris of the forest floor
Diet: Nocturnal carnivores - emerging at night to feed primarily on small invertebrates, such as beetles, ants, flies, and spiders
Tadpoles feed on algae and other organisms in the water
